channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: China Hangs on Xi’s Every Word. His Silence Also Speaks Volumes.
item.description: At the important Communist Party congress this week, the Chinese leader didn’t mention two long-repeated maxims. To many, it’s a warning of the turbulent times ahead.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:credit: Li Xueren/Xinhua, via Associated Press
item.media:description: China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, is expected to secure a precedent-defying third term at the end of the Communist Party congress.

item.title: Hu Jintao Was Escorted Out of China’s Congress, Raising Questions
item.description: A health scare? A brazen political gesture? Whatever else it was, the episode was awkward.
item.dc:creator: Chang Che
item.media:credit: Kevin Frayer/Getty Images
item.media:description: The unexpected departure of a former leader, Hu Jintao, standing, who apparently paused to speak to Mr. Xi before being escorted out, caused a brief stir during in proceedings that are usually tightly choreographed.

item.title: How Tumultuous Forces of Brexit Divided U.K.’s Conservative Party
item.description: Some experts link Liz Truss’s downfall to the ripple effect of Britain’s departure from the European Union and the bitter, ideologically opposed factions it created in her party.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Brexit supporters gathering in front of a statue of Winston Churchill in London on Jan. 21, 2020, to celebrate Britain leaving the European Union.

item.title: How Trump Could Resist the Jan. 6 Panel’s Subpoena
item.description: If the ex-president turns down the drama of testifying, his legal team could mount several constitutional and procedural arguments in court.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage and Alan Feuer
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
item.media:credit: Brittany Greeson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former President Donald J. Trump’s legal team could also invoke executive privilege in an attempt to ward off the subpoena.

item.title: Using Adoptions, Russia Turns Ukrainian Children Into Spoils of War
item.description: Thousands of Ukrainian children have been transferred to Russia. “I didn’t want to go,” one girl told The New York Times from a foster home near Moscow.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Evgeniy Maloletka/Associated Press
item.media:description: A broken window at a hospital in March in Mariupol, Ukraine. Russian officials have made clear that their goal is to replace any childhood attachment to home with a love for Russia.

item.title: Voters Stick to Pandemic-Era Habits, as Early Turnout Surges
item.description: More than 5.5 million people have cast ballots in person or by mail. Experts predict high turnout in the midterm elections.
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti
item.media:credit: Hannah Beier for The New York Times
item.media:description: A resident drops off a mail-in ballot in Philadelphia.

item.title: Who Gets the Last Word on Steve Jobs? He Might.
item.description: When Laurene Powell Jobs unveiled a website dedicated to the story of her late husband, historians wondered if it could change how influential people burnish their legacies.
item.dc:creator: Tripp Mickle
item.media:credit: Jim Gensheimer/San Jose Mercury News, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Steve Jobs spoke to the class of 2005 at Stanford. Material about Apple’s early years went to the university.

item.title: How New Yorkers Are Stepping In to Help Asylum Seekers
item.description: Volunteers are collecting donations, delivering pizzas and even opening up their homes to help Venezuelan migrants arriving by bus from Texas.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ilze Thielmann, left, Power Malu and Adama Bah, at the Port Authority Bus Terminal where they have spent their mornings assisting newly arrived migrants.

item.title: Did the Pandemic Change Your Personality? Possibly.
item.description: For more than two years, Covid disrupted social rituals and rites of passage. Now a recent study suggests we have become less extroverted, creative, agreeable and conscientious. The declines in some traits were sharper among young people.
item.dc:creator: Christine Chung
item.media:credit: Kaiti Sullivan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lucy Nguyen participates in a group scream at the Zionsville Youth Soccer Fields in Whitestown, Indiana.

item.title: Hassles of Cross-Border Trains Hamper EU’s Green Ambitions
item.description: One man is on a mission to find and suggest fixes for all of the flaws making international rail travel in Europe surprisingly hard. Getting more people on trains is key to meeting E.U. climate goals.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: At the railway station in Rumburk, Czech Republic, on the border with Germany. “We need to get more people on trains,” said Jon Worth, the self-appointed monitor of Europe’s railroad system.

item.title: For New York Governor, The Times Endorses Kathy Hochul
item.description: In-person voting begins on Oct. 29.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board
item.media:credit: Jingyu Lin for The New York Times

item.title: Not-So-Great Britain’s Conservative Crackup
item.description: Was Liz Truss a cat’s paw for a Boris Johnson comeback?
item.dc:creator: Maureen Dowd
item.media:credit: David Cliff/Associated Press

item.title: Biden Just Clobbered China’s Chip Industry
item.description: The latest American trade restrictions could significantly set back China’s semiconductor ambitions.
item.dc:creator: Farhad Manjoo
item.media:credit: Florence Lo/Reuters

item.title: The Three Blunders of Joe Biden
item.description: How the Biden White House has contributed to the Democratic Party’s midterm troubles.
item.dc:creator: Ross Douthat
item.media:credit: T.J. Kirkpatrick for The New York Times

item.title: Wonking Out: Facts, Feelings and Rural Politics
item.description: What explains small-town America’s sense of rage?
item.dc:creator: Paul Krugman
item.media:credit: Illustration by Sam Whitney/The New York Times; photograph by Ed Freeman

item.title: Remote Work Is Here to Stay. Lean In, Employers.
item.description: A baby boomlet may not have been 2021’s only productivity increase.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Grose
item.media:credit: Getty Images

item.title: The Price of Liberty Goes Up the Longer You Wait
item.description: A warning from John Brown remains true today.
item.dc:creator: Jamelle Bouie
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Augustus Washington, via National Portrait Gallery

item.title: Trauma Is the Best Comedy Material, but April 7 Was Not Funny
item.description: Comedy has helped me process the Israel-Palestine conflict. Then I was in a terrorist attack.
item.dc:creator: Noam Shuster Eliassi
item.media:credit: Ariel Schalit/Associated Press
item.media:description: The scene of a shooting attack in Tel Aviv on April 7.

item.title: Generative A.I. Is Here. Who Should Control It?
item.description: Emad Mostaque, the founder of Stability AI, says his Stable Diffusion image generator is the key to unlocking creativity. His critics say it’s a potential threat.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Roose, Casey Newton, Davis Land, Paula Szuchman, Corey Schreppel, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Elisheba Ittoop
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: The 2022 Midterms: Is Wisconsin the Future of America?
item.description: In Wisconsin, aggressive and methodical gerrymandering has allowed Republicans to cement their political power. Can Democrats ever make inroads?
item.dc:creator: ‘The Run-Up’ Team
item.media:credit: ilbusca/ Getty Images

item.title: Facing Surgery? Here’s How to Prepare.
item.description: The best way to navigate a surgery recommendation is to ask a lot of questions.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer
item.media:credit: Illustration by Joan Wong; Photographs by Getty Images

item.title: Remembering Loretta Lynn
item.description: A conversation about the country music titan’s sly radicalism and the many readings and misreadings of her work.
item.media:credit: Ethan Miller/Reuters

item.title: Some Palestinians Move Into Caves to Resist Israeli Expulsion
item.description: Israel’s Supreme Court has ordered the removal of about 1,200 Palestinians from their villages in the occupied West Bank. The United Nations says that could amount to a war crime.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Samar Hazboun for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of the Abu Sabha family in July inside a cave in Khirbet al-Fakheit, a village in the West Bank. The family’s home was destroyed three times, so they turned to the cave.

item.title: ALCS: Astros on Verge of Eliminating Yankees
item.description: Houston’s pitchers combined to allow only three hits in Game 3, keeping their team a perfect 6-0 this postseason.
item.dc:creator: David Waldstein
item.media:credit: Michelle Farsi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Matt Carpenter and the Yankees were unable to produce any offense against Cristian Javier and the Astros bullpen on Saturday.

item.title: Hurricane Roslyn Strengthens to Category 4 and Heads Toward Mexico
item.description: Roslyn became a Category 4 hurricane on Saturday. Forecasters warned it could bring coastal flooding and dangerous winds to cities along the Pacific Coast.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: CIRA/NOAA
item.media:description: Roslyn is a Category 4 hurricane, forecast to reach the coast of west-central Mexico on Sunday.

item.title: NYC Increases Police in Subways to Combat Crime
item.description: With less than three weeks until Election Day, Gov. Kathy Hochul is trying to address a troubling series of violent incidents on the subway.
item.dc:creator: Emma G. Fitzsimmons
item.media:credit: Dakota Santiago for The New York Times
item.media:description: New York Police Department crime scene investigators responding to a fight that led to a man falling to his death at Roosevelt Station in Queens on Monday.

item.title: Work Burnout: How to Spot Symptoms and What to Do
item.description: Here’s how to recognize the physical symptoms of work-related stress — and what to do about them.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer
item.media:credit: Alva Skog

item.title: How to Break a Phone Addiction
item.description: Whether smartphone overuse constitutes a true addiction is still up for debate, but experts say there are ways to scale down.
item.dc:creator: Annie Sneed
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: How to Prevent Memory Loss
item.description: A new book by a renowned brain expert says there are a few simple things we can do to prevent memory decline as we age.
item.dc:creator: Hope Reese
item.category: The Complete Guide to Memory: The Science of Strengthening Your Mind (Book)
item.media:credit: Mikyung Lee

item.title: The Best Exercises to Prevent Lower Back Pain
item.description: Back pain is common and complicated. But altering your workout to build control and stability can help prevent it.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Fairbank
item.media:credit: Cole Barash for The New York Times

item.title: What Are Your ‘Non-Negotiables’? Readers Share Wellness Rituals
item.description: Reading Nancy Drew. Watching the birds every day. Counting yellow doors. Thousands of Times readers shared their wellness “non-negotiables.”
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum and Andrea Chronopoulos
item.media:credit: Andrea Chronopoulos

item.title: ‘Black Adam’ Review: Heroism, but Paint It Black
item.description: Dwayne Johnson stars in this overstuffed superhero film about an ancient figure granted god powers.
item.dc:creator: Maya Phillips

item.title: How to Solve Hard Crosswords
item.description: Friday, Saturday and Sunday bring some of the hardest puzzles of the week.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
item.media:credit: Thomas Merceron
